prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for ending free friend rides in my car?
My friend always hops rides everywhere in my car. I fill up the tank and pick him up at his house and drop him back off safely at home. This past weekend he put 10 in gas because I forgot my purse home and yesterday he asked me back for it. He has ridden in my car hundreds of times without putting gas. Am I an asshole for saying find your way around in the future?
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. So, the situation is that their friend has been taking free rides in their car a lot. The author fills up the gas, picks up the friend, and drops them off. This has happened hundreds of times without the friend contributing to gas. But this past weekend, the friend put $10 in gas when the author forgot their purse at home, and then asked for it back. Now the author is ending the free rides and is asking if they're an asshole.

Hmm. So, the friend usually doesn't pay for gas, but once they did. The author is ending the rides, telling the friend to find their own way. The question is whether the author is in the wrong.

First, I need to consider the context. The friend has been using the car for free, which the author is okay with up until now. The friend only contributed once when they forgot the purse. The author might feel that since the friend never pays, they're taking advantage. But when the friend did pay, they wanted their money back. That seems odd. Maybe the friend thought it was a loan? Or maybe they just wanted to help temporarily.

The author is ending the arrangement. Is that fair? Well, the friend has been using the car without contributing. The author might be justified in setting boundaries. If the friend expects to ride for free, but the author is covering all costs, that's a one-sided arrangement. The author is within their rights to stop if they want. However, maybe the friend relies on these rides, so the author should have communicated earlier. But since the author is ending it now, perhaps not in the wrong.

Wait, the friend only put $10 in once. If the author is ending it because of that one instance, maybe that's a bit harsh. But the author is pointing out that the friend has never contributed before. The friend might have thought it was a one-time thing. The author is saying "find your way around in the future," which is telling the friend to find their own transportation. That's reasonable if the author is tired of covering all the costs. So, maybe the author isn't in the wrong here. The friend might be the one who's inconsiderate for always relying on the author. So the answer would be B, the author is not in the wrong.
